definition: Autosomal recessive quantitative or qualitative defect of the platelet GPIb-IX-V receptor that binds vWF. Impaired platelet-to-vWF adhesion causes mucocutaneous bleeding. Smear shows giant platelets with mild-to-moderate thrombocytopenia.

images.alt: Bernard-Soulier: big platelets and defective adhesion

why_it_matters: Classic congenital adhesion defect. Distinguishing it from von Willebrand disease and Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a common exam task.
how_youll_see_it: Epistaxis, easy bruising, gingival bleeding since childhood.
Labs: platelet count low or low-normal; bleeding time prolonged; PT and PTT normal.
problem_solving: Ristocetin aggregation is absent and does not correct with normal plasma (receptor missing).
Desmopressin is not helpful; consider platelet transfusion for major bleeds or procedures.
Avoid aspirin and NSAIDs; use antifibrinolytics for dental or ENT bleeding.

differentials.hint: ristocetin defect corrects with normal plasma; platelet count normal
aggregation defect to ADP, epinephrine, collagen; ristocetin normal
isolated thrombocytopenia without congenital giant platelets

tricks: B for Big platelets and Bad binding to vWF.
Adhesion problem (GPIb) vs aggregation problem (GPIIb/IIIa in Glanzmann).
exam_appearance: Teen with lifelong nosebleeds, giant platelets, abnormal ristocetin that does not correct with mixing: Bernard-Soulier.
Dental extraction planning in congenital adhesion disorder: give platelets or antifibrinolytics; avoid aspirin.
treatment: Local measures and antifibrinolytics for minor bleeds.
Platelet transfusion for severe bleeding or surgery.
red_flags: Uncontrolled mucosal hemorrhage or menorrhagia needs urgent hemostatic support.
Repeated transfusions carry alloimmunization risk; coordinate with hematology.
algorithm: Mucocutaneous bleeding with large platelets -> order platelet function testing.
Absent ristocetin response that does not correct -> Bernard-Soulier likely.

cases.stem: 16-year-old with lifelong epistaxis; smear shows giant platelets.
cases.teaching: GPIb deficiency causes defective adhesion; mixing with normal plasma does not correct.

cases.stem: Adult with congenital adhesion defect needs dental surgery.
cases.answer: Plan antifibrinolytic; give platelet transfusion if significant bleeding risk.
cases.teaching: Desmopressin will not fix receptor absence; use platelets when needed.
